thread.title: Bernie Sanders' schtick

author: Nia-Malika Henderson
title: Bernie Sanders' schtick
text:
Story highlights Bernie Sanders is contending with (and embracing) a version of himself that is pure caricature Sanders has suggested inviting Larry David to a campaign rally Washington (CNN) Bernie Sanders is having a moment.
And his moment looks nothing like what many people -- not even Bernie Sanders himself -- would likely have predicted for the super-serious Democratic socialist president candidate. Known for his dour, everything-is-awful approach to politics, Sanders has more recently become something else entirely. He has morphed into a kind of walking punchline for a joke that he is (sometimes) in on.
There is #BabiesForBernie, a viral Internet meme where toddlers embrace grandpa chic.
Related: #BabiesForBernie catches on social media
He "danced" on Ellen -- really, he just pointed and walked.
Read More On Comedy Central's "The Nightly Show," Larry Wilmore easily convinced Sanders to don a pair of sunglasses. And with a slump, Sanders had the "Weekend at Bernie's" look down pat.
Just as Sanders embarks on his national close-up -- 15 million people watched the CNN debate -- he is now contending with (and embracing) a version of himself that is pure caricature.
8 photos: Politicians and their 'SNL' alter egos 8 photos: Politicians and their 'SNL' alter egos Actress recently Kate McKinnon caught the notice of the political and entertainment worlds with her parody of Hillary Clinton, portraying her as a calculating and power-hungry politician. Click through to see the storied history of "SNL" and political parody: Hide Caption 1 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their 'SNL' alter egos Actress Amy Poehler, left, also played Hillary Clinton in several "Saturday Night Live" skits. Hide Caption 2 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their 'SNL' alter egos President Bill Clinton, left, laughs with lookalike Darrell Hammond of "Saturday Night Live" at the 53rd annual dinner of the Radio and Television Correspondents' Association in 1997. Hide Caption 3 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their 'SNL' alter egos Singer Miley Cyrus, right, played Michele Bachmann in a "Saturday Night Live" digital short parody of her song "We Can't Stop" about the federal government shutdown in 2013. Hide Caption 4 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their 'SNL' alter egos Actress Tina Fey's parody of Sarah Palin, left, on "Saturday Night Live" became a favorite during the 2008 elections. Hide Caption 5 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their 'SNL' alter egos Actor Jason Sudeikis, right, created Joe Biden's "Saturday Night Live" alter ego during the 2012 elections during a skit about the vice presidential debate. Hide Caption 6 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their 'SNL' alter egos "Saturday Night Live" often writes skits mocking presidential debates soon after they happened. Pictured from left: Mitt Romney, Barack Obama, Jason Sudeikis and Jay Pharoah from the 2012 election. Hide Caption 7 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their 'SNL' alter egos "Saturday Night Live" aired its own presidential debate for the 2004 election with Seth Meyers, left, as John Kerry and Will Forte as President George W. Bush. Hide Caption 8 of 8 Larry David on "Saturday Night Live" went full Bernie with hardly any effort at all.
"Hello, hello, hello, enough with the hellos," David as Sanders said in the "SNL" debate send-up. "Let's do this."
And from there, David riffed on Sanders' get-off-my-lawn persona, shouting the entire time.
"We're doomed! We need a revolution! Millions of people on the streets! We gotta do something and we gotta do it now!"
Not to mention the underwear drying on the radiator image -- TMI and kinda perfect.
Opinion: Sanders' best weapon may be Larry David
Returning the favor , Sanders went on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" and went all meta, impersonating David, his doppelganger. Or perhaps he was just being Bernie Sanders. It was hard to tell.
His campaign says part of the flood of Sanders late night appearances is simply because he is getting invited -- which wasn't the case earlier.
"We have opportunities now that we didn't have before. We are getting invites," said Tad Devine, a senior Sanders adviser. "He is getting more comfortable doing stuff like that and he has come to accept that it's part of the process."
Poll: Strong debate helps push Clinton over Sanders in Iowa
But the Sanders viewers are seeing isn't necessarily the one that has liberal voters excited. The Vermont senator got to where he is by being an unapologetic "democratic socialist," giving high-impact speeches on income inequality, campaign finance reform and the high cost of college education.
Then again, when shown the clip on ABC's "This Week," Sanders said David's "SNL" rendition of him -- the hands, the yelling, the Brooklyn accent -- was spot-on.
"I think we'll use Larry at our next rally," Sanders said. "He does me better than I do."
